description:
Corythoichthys intestinalis, commonly known as the intestinal pipefish, is a species of marine fish belonging to the family Syngnathidae. This pipefish species is found in the Indo-Pacific region, ranging from the Red Sea and East Africa to northern Australia and the Philippines.

The Corythoichthys intestinalis is a small, slender fish, typically measuring around 10-15 centimeters in length. It has a distinctive elongated, tube-like snout, which is characteristic of pipefish species. The body is covered in bony plates, and the fish has a distinctive ring-like pattern along its length.

This species is known to inhabit coral reef environments, often found in close association with seagrass beds and macroalgal communities. It is primarily a bottom-dwelling species, using its prehensile tail to cling to marine vegetation and other structures.

The Corythoichthys intestinalis is known to feed on small crustaceans and other small invertebrates found in its habitat. It is also recognized for its unique reproductive behavior, where the male carries the fertilized eggs in a brood pouch until they hatch.

Overall, the Corythoichthys intestinalis is an interesting and unique member of the pipefish family, contributing to the biodiversity of coral reef ecosystems in the Indo-Pacific region.
